articles.headline: Catalonia’s Independence Vote Descends Into Chaos and Clashes
articles.snippet: Hundreds were injured as riot police officers, some firing rubber bullets, dispersed voters, Catalan officials said. Dozens of police officers were also hurt.
articles.abstract: Hundreds were injured as riot police officers, some firing rubber bullets, dispersed voters, Catalan officials said. Dozens of police officers were also hurt.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Catalonia’s defiant attempt to stage an independence referendum descended into chaos on Sunday, with hundreds injured in clashes with police in one of the gravest tests of Spain’s democracy since the end of the Franco dictatorship in the 1970s.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Back at Full Strength, Supreme Court Faces a Momentous Term
articles.snippet: Justices will hear cases on how elections are conducted, on the right to privacy in the digital age and on whether religion can justify discrimination.
articles.abstract: Justices will hear cases on how elections are conducted, on the right to privacy in the digital age and on whether religion can justify discrimination.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which was short-handed and slumbering for more than a year after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, is returning to the bench on Monday with a far-reaching docket that renews its central role in American life.

articles.headline: Trump Says Tillerson Is ‘Wasting His Time’ on North Korea
articles.snippet: Undercutting his secretary of state, the president told him not to bother with negotiations. “Save your energy Rex,” he wrote on Twitter.
articles.abstract: Undercutting his secretary of state, the president told him not to bother with negotiations. “Save your energy Rex,” he wrote on Twitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump undercut his own secretary of state on Sunday, calling his effort to open lines of communication with North Korea a waste of time, and seeming to rule out a diplomatic resolution to the nuclear-edged confrontation with Pyongyang.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Europe’s On-Demand Economy Draws Complaints. And Regulators.
articles.snippet: As self-employed work forces and nontraditional work contracts proliferate, governments and courts are considering tougher protections.
articles.abstract: As self-employed work forces and nontraditional work contracts proliferate, governments and courts are considering tougher protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mohaan Biswas was speeding takeout orders to customers in London for the online food delivery start-up Deliveroo when he fell from his motorbike, breaking his foot in two places.

articles.headline: Bitcoin Bug Bites Japan and South Korea as China Clamps Down
articles.snippet: Just as China asserts its authority over virtual currencies, other investors in the region are speculating on their value in growing exchanges.
articles.abstract: Just as China asserts its authority over virtual currencies, other investors in the region are speculating on their value in growing exchanges.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Until recently, China was a center of Bitcoin activity while the rest of Asia looked on with little interest.

articles.headline: As Catalans Voted, ‘Dying With Fear’ at High School Turned Polling Place
articles.snippet: Students at the Moisès Broggi school created barricades to foil the police and used diversions to sneak ballot boxes to safety.
articles.abstract: Students at the Moisès Broggi school created barricades to foil the police and used diversions to sneak ballot boxes to safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — At some point on Sunday afternoon, as riot police officers forced their way into polling places all over the city, the Moisès Broggi high school in Barcelona became a fortress.

articles.headline: A Media Empire Loses Its King. What Now?
articles.snippet: S.I. Newhouse Jr. was a self-effacing executive who somehow managed to serve as the public face of a brash, glitzy magazine company. How, exactly, will Condé Nast go on without him?
articles.abstract: S.I. Newhouse Jr. was a self-effacing executive who somehow managed to serve as the public face of a brash, glitzy magazine company. How, exactly, will Condé Nast go on without him?
articles.lead_paragraph: Condé Nast was named after Condé Montrose Nast, who purchased Vogue in 1909. But the glossy magazine company has long been synonymous with its unassuming leader, Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., who became chairman in 1975.

articles.headline: A Burst of Gunfire, a Pause, Then Carnage in Las Vegas That Would Not Stop
articles.snippet: Thousands of concertgoers found themselves turned into targets, and in the chaos, many tried to lie flat, with no idea they were being fired upon from above.
articles.abstract: Thousands of concertgoers found themselves turned into targets, and in the chaos, many tried to lie flat, with no idea they were being fired upon from above.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — At first, it sounded like fireworks — a loud, crackling noise. Then the awful realization began to spread, unevenly, through the huge crowd.
articles.byline: By Ken Belson, Jennifer Medina and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Stephen Paddock, Las Vegas Suspect, Was a Gambler Who Drew Little Attention
articles.snippet: The man who police say killed dozens of people and then himself Sunday night was described as a retiree who lived quietly, liked to gamble, and had no criminal record.
articles.abstract: The man who police say killed dozens of people and then himself Sunday night was described as a retiree who lived quietly, liked to gamble, and had no criminal record.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was a high-stakes gambler recognized in the casinos of Nevada. He dabbled in real estate investments in Texas. His last known full-time employment was 30 years ago. He was twice divorced. He had a pilot’s license and had owned two single-engine planes.
articles.byline: By Jose A. Del Real and Jonah Engel Bromwich

articles.headline: Facebook’s Russia-Linked Ads Came in Many Disguises
articles.snippet: The Russia-linked ads used to influence the 2016 election included those from a fake gun-rights group, a bogus gay rights group and even a phony dog lovers group.
articles.abstract: The Russia-linked ads used to influence the 2016 election included those from a fake gun-rights group, a bogus gay rights group and even a phony dog lovers group.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Russians who posed as Americans on Facebook last year tried on quite an array of disguises.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Gunman’s Vantage Point and Preparations Opened the Way for Mass Slaughter
articles.snippet: Firing on a crowd from a 32nd-floor hotel room gave the gunman in the Las Vegas shooting an advantage that allowed him to inflict widespread carnage.
articles.abstract: Firing on a crowd from a 32nd-floor hotel room gave the gunman in the Las Vegas shooting an advantage that allowed him to inflict widespread carnage.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his hotel room on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas, Stephen Paddock would have looked down upon a crowd of more than 20,000 people, surging to the final sets of a country music festival.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: G.M. and Ford Lay Out Plans to Expand Electric Models
articles.snippet: General Motors says it will add at least 20 electric vehicles to its lineup by 2023. Ford followed with its own initiative with 13 offerings.
articles.abstract: General Motors says it will add at least 20 electric vehicles to its lineup by 2023. Ford followed with its own initiative with 13 offerings.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — China has said it will eventually ban gasoline-powered cars. California may be moving in the same direction. That pressure has set off a scramble by the world’s car companies to embrace electric vehicles.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Neal E. Boudette
